results.title: Forest to foundry
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Wundowie, Western Australia is known for its sawmills and its pig-iron foundry. It is in the midst of the jarrah country and two sawmills produce high grade timber. Iron ore is brought to Wundowie from the quarries and there reduced to pig-iron in blast furnaces with the charcoal produced from the timber waste.

results.title: The Forest regions of Canada
results.creator_credit: Herb Taylor, Frank Spiller and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A country-wide survey of the changing technology of lumbering and the system of long-range reforestation. Shown is a machine that strips a tree of branches, then neatly bites through the base and lowers it onto a timber carrier; and a machine that reduces logs to wood chips right in the forest, for easier transport to the mill. Animated maps show the locations of the various forest regions of Canada. (Award: Santarem).

results.title: The Forest of trees and logs
results.creator_credit: Jerome Kurtz, Michael Halperin, H/K Films and K Films
results.brief_description: The forest is explored as a place of life - an environment with inter-relationships harbouring the living, providing food, and which, even in decay brings forth vitality. Our understanding of the role forests play in the biosphere of the planet may help us aid the forests to return to the grandeur which once was theirs.

results.title: Forest murmurs
results.brief_description: Presents the beauty of a public park, a bubbling brook, sparkling water, and verdant growth. But gradually bits of paper, tin cans, and broken bottles, bring discord. A plea against litter in public parks and forests.

results.title: Forest heritage
results.creator_credit: Roy Layzell, Andrew Rice and Esso Oil Company
results.brief_description: The film gives a picture of life in the New Forest in Hampshire, featuring the ponies, the ancient customs and historical remains of the Forest, and the work of the Forestry Commission.

results.title: Forest fire suppression
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Cherry, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Live action, animated sketches and maps are used to provide a detailed demonstration of how a forest fire is brought under control. The film describes the various factors - water supply, road transportation, type of timber stands, and direction of wind - which firefighters take into account in planning their attack and deploying equipment. It shows the actual fighting of a fire, and the mopping-up operations and close watch that must follow to safeguard against a renewed outbreak.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lawrence Cherry, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Forest fire control
results.brief_description: The south-west of Western Australia is the main forest area of the state and extensive fire control methods are established there. Look-out towers, often built on a tall Karri tree, are connected by telephone with Central Control. During the summer these are manned 24 hours a day. When a fire is sighted, its exact locality is plotted and Central Control immediately despatches fire-fighting equipment to the spot. Water from a storage tank and from individual spray packs is most effective in the early stages. As soon as some control has been reached special rakes are used to rake back the ashes and undergrowth. The area is patrolled until it is declared safe. The film makes the point that it is harder to extinguish fires then to prevent them.

results.title: The Forerunner
results.creator_credit: John Heyer and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Professor C.H. Munro introduces Australia’s water problem - the periodic cycles of flood and drought and the first major step in its solution, the Snowy Mountains scheme. The first part shows floods in town and country areas and rescue teams at work; the second, drought and a family forced to abandon their property; finally, the aims of the Snowy Mountains Scheme and some of the work in progress. Little commentary is used. Ballads and natural sound accompany evocative visuals.

results.title: The Force of gravity
results.creator_credit: Lothar Wolff, McGraw-Hill Films and National Academy of Sciences (U.S.)
results.brief_description: Our attempt to understand gravitation, especially in its relation to cosmology and geophysics; the views of the Egyptians and the greeks, the later work of Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo and Newton and modern methods of studying and measuring gravity in different parts of the earth’s surface, with an explanation of the effect of the moon’s gravitational pull on the earth.
